caption: Figure 1: The privacy curves for the subsampled Laplace mechanism under the remove and add neighboring relations respectively.
description: This figure shows the privacy curves for a subsampled Laplace mechanism after 1, 2, and 8 iterations under both the remove and add neighboring relations.  The x-axis represents epsilon (ε), a parameter in differential privacy that bounds the privacy loss, and the y-axis represents delta (δ), another parameter that bounds the probability of privacy failure.  The different lines show the privacy curves for various numbers of composition. The figure demonstrates that the worst-case datasets under the add and remove relations separately do not necessarily hold when the relations are combined.
section: No Worst-case Pair of Datasets under Add/Remove Relation

caption: Figure 2: Plots of the smallest noise multiplier σ required to achieve certain privacy parameters for the subsampled Gaussian mechanism with varying sampling rates under add/remove. Each line shows a specific value of ε for either Poisson subsampling or sampling without replacement. The parameter δ is fixed to 10⁻⁶ for all lines.
description: This figure shows how the required noise multiplier (σ) for achieving (ε, δ)-differential privacy changes with different sampling rates (γ) for both Poisson subsampling and sampling without replacement.  Different lines represent different privacy parameters (ε) while keeping δ constant at 10⁻⁶.  It highlights the significant differences in the required noise multiplier between these two sampling methods, especially at lower sampling rates.

caption: Figure 3: Hockey-stick divergence of the Laplace mechanism when sampling without replacement under ~s. The worst-case pair of datasets depends on the value of ε.
description: The figure shows the hockey-stick divergence for three pairs of neighboring datasets with respect to ε when using the subsampled Laplace mechanism with sampling without replacement and the substitution neighboring relation.  The worst-case pair of datasets depends on the value of ε, indicating that a single worst-case pair doesn't exist for all values of ε.

caption: Figure 4: Hockey-stick divergence for the Gaussian mechanism under substitution when sampling without replacement using a dominating pair of distributions. The dominating pair of distributions is constructed using a point-wise maximum of the privacy curve for a single iteration as seen in the left plot. The right plot compares the privacy curve from self-composing the dominating pair of distributions with a lower bound obtained from self-composing the PLD that corresponds to the blue line in the left plot. The difference between the blue and the dotted line corresponds to the difference between using the PLD and RDP accountants for Poisson subsampling under add/remove.
description: This figure visualizes the hockey-stick divergence for the Gaussian mechanism under substitution with sampling without replacement. The left plot shows how a dominating pair of distributions is constructed using the point-wise maximum of the privacy curve for a single iteration.  The right plot then compares the privacy curve obtained from self-composing this dominating pair with a lower bound derived from self-composing the Privacy Loss Distribution (PLD). The difference between these curves highlights the discrepancy between using PLD and Rényi Differential Privacy (RDP) accountants for Poisson subsampling under the add/remove relation.
section: D Constructing a Dominating Pair of Distributions for the Gaussian Mechanism
